comments.commentBody: Now, although it is not high among my entertainment priorities to watch grown men and women making 2000 consecutive left turns, from a strictly linguistic point of view, the Times is mis-correcting the name from NASCAR to Nascar.  NASCAR is what the organization calls itself.  It has the right to call itself whatever it wants to, and the name is a genuine acronym for National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.  It isn't even a contrived acronym, like the HELP trucks on the Thruway (Highway Emergency Local Patrol--come on, that's not really how you say it in English!)  But I digress.  And it's a registered trademark.  And "Nascar" is not a correction--it's just plain wrong.

Agreed. Rock solid analysis. I'm 55 years old and have followed all the mentioned coaches and sports. Same thing with the greatest athletes. Part of their job is figuring out how to make the team win...not just putting up great individual stats. When it comes to the best of the best.....championships are the defining criteria.

This puzzle, thankfully, ended a three-day spate of DNFs for me, but it was a slog. I especially had to keep pounding away at the far NE and the SW until I finally made it. Even though I filled 56A correctly, I couldn't figure out the root expression to which I added the TY until I read Patrick's explanation. Still, the wonderfully witty and ingeniously constructed theme gave me a kick after the hard work was over.

I'm totally with steve I on the NASCAR spelling issue. The organization's name is an acronym, so there's nothing to correct, although contrary to steve's assertion, it is slightly contrived. The "Auto" in the name is clumsily redundant and is obviously there solely to flesh out the acronym and produce the felicitous syllable CAR. As far as the Times's style is concerned, it makes as much sense to initial-cap NASCAR as to write Nypd or Usmc.

I don't watch TimesCast (no high-speed connection) but as a retired  provincial newspaperman and aspiring fuddy-duddy I find the idea of sharing the daily editorial conference ridiculous, even more so because it's edited. I have participated in a few and at its best it was a free-wheeling discussion with more than a few disagreements, un-PC remarks and ribald language. Finally the managing editor would step in and say "Why don't we play the (Cuban missile crisis/local political scandal/the story the publisher is interested in) and we would agree and go back to our desks.(BTW, the last story idea was known as an FOD, Front Office Deal.) I can't imagine how it would have been if we were being filmed for the Internet. We would certainly have censored ourselves. Of course the Times is of another magnitude but I don't see the point. I might reconsider if Goldman Sachs televises its board meetings.

Accuracy takes time, finding the facts takes time, critical reading and thinking take time, too. We have become so enamored of speed that we suffer from a lack of these; I hope the New York Times can abstrain from entering the headlong, breathless media rush so there will be some news source we can trust.

I hope also that reporters at NYT will abstain from presenting their judgments of news items in their stories (e.g., "Obama Tries to Explain Health Care Bill to Critical Audience in Nation" rather than "Details of Health Care Bill")

But ultimately, without a culture and a people that will take time to think, this may all be academic.

Good for you, Mo, to see you'd lived in these denials yourself.

It goes on around the world -- even in advanced, high-tech, consumer-rich countries such as the one where I live.

At a recent school assembly to welcome the new, first-year kids (all institutional life begins anew early April here), the school had twelve speakers lined up to give speeches. As it turned out, eleven were men. And the only woman appeared all dressed in ceremonial kimono -- as if even she wanted to admit that she knew a woman's most proper role is as ceremonial token.

When I proceeded to ask people afterward if they'd noted anything odd in this assembly, none did. No girls could recognize the skewed priorities for them, and their gender, as modeled before them.

To see one's culture, as Hemingway said -- as Edith Wharton and Gertrude Stein taught him -- one has to get out of one's culture. But too many cultures around the world simply provide comfort zones, whence no one escapes.

Americans fancy their own churches, corporate silos, and consumer niches as empowering zones -- but thanks to your column today, perhaps more will question how too many yet live in massive denial, massively abetting the powers that be.

Organized religions have been suppressing women for thousands of years. The few that, even today, dare ordain a woman are still under fire from the traditionalists. The same traditions translate into ignoring the harm caused by the wicked behavior of a few.

The recent health care reforms passed by congress were endorsed by the sisters of the church over the protests of the fathers of the church. Will they be able to stand up for what is right in this issue?

And worse, it is more interested in hiding the crimes of the adult representatives of that institution rather than helping the children whom they have abused.

This is more than just a sin to be dealt with in some mythical afterlife. This is a CRIME, which has been perpetuated over decades. And for the most part the crime has gone unpunished, or even acknowledged.

It is beyond my comprehension how can smart people like you can continue to associate themselves with this institution. Now that is a sin.
